intro_1.headline: Introduction
copy: These birds represent three groups of toucans sampled by John, Jason, and Alex during their Amazonian expedition, as well as other earlier Field Museum expeditions to Amazonia.
As you can see, these groups were found along the boundaries between Areas of Endemism—regions containing species unique to that area.

intro_2.headline: Introduction
copy: For years, scientists believed these toucans to be different populations of the same species: the Ivory-billed Araçari (Pteroglossus azara).
But the work of John, Jason, and Alex’s team is revealing that perhaps the birds’ relationships—and the Areas of Endemism—need to be re-evaluated.
Replicate the team’s experiments to find out why.

range.headline: Range Map
copy: Populations A and B are interbreeding with each other, but neither is interbreeding with population C on the Japurá’s north bank—these toucans are evolving in isolation within their own tiny territory.
To see if this same pattern held true for other animals, the team tried another experiment: comparing bird parasites.

lice.instructions: Take a tissue sample from each chewing lice.

conclusion_1.headline: Conclusion
copy: First, you and the team have redefined the family trees of both Ivory-billed Araçari and their chewing lice, proving that there’s more diversity in Amazonia than previously understood.

conclusion_2.headline: onclusion
copy: And you’ve uncovered evidence that confirms the existence of a previously unrecognized Area of Endemism (recently named the Jaú). Congratulations!
Through studies like these, we can continue to identify species that are evolving in isolation and take appropriate actions to protect both them and their habitats.

modals.headline: Step 1:  Physical Comparison
copy: The first stage in determining family relationships between birds involves detailed comparisons of their physical traits: their size, coloration, and even their birdcalls.

next.copy: Let's begin by taking measurements of each Ivory-billed Araçari population

modals.headline: Did you see the differences between the birds' sizes?

answers.headline: Wrong answer...
answers.subheadline: Remember, millimeters are tiny units of measurement.

modals.copy: When the team measured the wings, bills, tails, and other features of serveral specimens from each Ivory-billed Araçari population, the birds appeared to be virtually the same size

next.copy: Next, look at each bird to see if the colors and patterns of their feathers and bills differ

modals.copy: When the team compared the appearance of several specimens from each Ivory-billed Araçari population, their plumage appeared to be virtually identical, but the coloration of their bills and eye rings differed slightly.

next.copy: Now listen to each population’s bird call to compare them. Keep in mind that the recordings feature both calm individuals and excited groups of birds.

modals.headline: Did you hear many differences in the way these birds called to one another?
modals.copy: When the team compared the calls and sonograms of several specimens from each Ivory-billed Araçari population, they all appeared to be “singing from the same songbook.”

next.copy: You’ve confirmed the team’s results by demonstrating that the three Ivory-billed Araçari populations appear to be almost identical—that’s why they’ve long been considered members of the same species.

modals.copy: You’ve also confirmed that the only apparent difference between them is bill and eye-ring coloration, which is why each population has its own subspecies name.

next.copy: Let’s see if the DNA of these birds tells the same story...

modals.headline: Step 2: Genetic Comparison
modals.copy: Today’s scientists don’t have to rely on appearances alone to classify species. They have another tool in their toolbox—genetic sequencing.

next.copy: Tweeze off a tissue sample from each bird and send it out for sequencing to pinpoint how closely related these Ivory-billed Araçari are to one another.

modals.headline: Which bird’s gene sequence is different?
modals.subhead: Slide the highlighter along gene sequences and select the one that is different.

next.copy: When the team compared samples of DNA taken from several specimens of the three Ivory-billed Araçari populations, the DNA of population C didn’t match the other two!

modals.headline: Good job!
copy: Both you and the team have now demonstrated that population C (P.a. azara) is genetically distinct—a completely separate species from the other two Ivory-billed Araçari populations, not just a subspecies.
In other words, the family tree would show that A and B share the same twig, while C branches off on its own.

next.copy: To understand how this may have happened, the team mapped the geographic ranges of each population...

modals.headline: Step 3: Range Mapping
modals.copy: When the team took a closer look at the geographical ranges of each Ivory-billed Araçari population, they noticed that the Japurá River seems to play a role in their relationship.

next.copy: Let’s go back to the map to take another look.

modals.headline: Step 4: Parasite Comparison
modals.copy: The team found that all three Ivory-billed Araçari populations appeared to be carrying the same species of chewing lice (Myrsidea dorotheae). But as we’ve learned, appearances can be deceiving.

next.copy: Compare the gene sequences of each toucan population’s chewing lice to see if any are different.

modals.copy: When the team compared samples of DNA taken from several specimens of chewing lice found on the three Ivory-billed Araçari populations, the genes of the lice on toucan population C were unique.

modals.headline: Good job!
copy: You’ve now demonstrated that the lice on population C are genetically distinct from the lice found on the other two Ivory-billed Araçari populations.
You’ve also proven that a pattern exists: the Japurá River appears to isolate both the birds and lice in population C, preventing them from interbreeding with populations A and B.
